comments:
Test failures in nightly builds like:

Program did not suspend, launch terminated. 

junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Program did not suspend, launch 
terminated.
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.AbstractDebugTest.launchAndWait
(AbstractDebugTest.java:235)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.AbstractDebugTest.launchAndWait
(AbstractDebugTest.java:195)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.AbstractDebugTest.launchToLineBreakpoint
(AbstractDebugTest.java:389)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.AbstractDebugTest.launchToLineBreakpoint
(AbstractDebugTest.java:373)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.core.RunToLineTests.runToLine
(RunToLineTests.java:155)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.core.RunToLineTests.testRunToLineSkipBreakpoint
(RunToLineTests.java:112)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke
(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke
(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.DebugSuite$1.run(DebugSuite.java:53)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:534)

Fixed.

The problem was in "RunToLineHandler". The handler only re-enabled the 
breakpoint manager (i.e. turned skip breakpoints off), if the breakpoint hit 
in the target was the run-to-line breakpoint. However, the test could 
terminated the target before the run-to-line handler had a chance to clean up 
(due to ordering of event listeners). (this would clear the breakpoint 
collection held by the target, and had the effect of leaving the manager in a 
disabled (skip) state).

The fix is to re-enable them manager no matter what the reason the suspension 
is for. I.e. the manager is set to skip (or not, depending on the pref). The 
next time the target suspends, the run to line operation is done and the skip 
state should be restored.

Fixed in RunToLineHandler.

traces.message: Program did not suspend, launch  terminated.
